metadata.titleEn: Qilian Mountains integrated observatory network: Dataset of Heihe integrated observatory network (Phenology camera observation data set of Mixed forest superstation-2019)
metadata.description:
The dataset contains the phenological camera observation data of the Mixed forest station in the downstream of Heihe integrated observatory network from August 28, 2019 to December 31, 2019. The instrument was developed and data processed by Beijing Normal University. The phenomenon camera integrates data acquisition and data transmission functions. The camera captures data by look-downward with a resolution of 1280×720. For the calculation of the greenness index and phenology, the relative greenness index (GCC, Green Chromatic Coordinate, calculated by GCC=G/(R+G+B)) needs to be calculated according to the region of interest, then the invalid value filling and filtering smoothing are performed, and finally the key phenological parameters are determined according to the growth curve fitting, such as the growth season start date, Peak, growth season end, etc. For coverage, first, select images with less intense illumination, then divide the image into vegetation and soil, calculate the proportion of vegetation pixels in each image in the calculation area. After the time series data is extracted, the original coverage data is smoothed and filtered according to the time window specified by the user, and the filtered result is the final time series coverage. This data set includes relative greenness index (Gcc).
Please refer to Liu et al. (2018) for sites information in the Citation section.

background: Arid and semiarid regions represent approximately 30 % of the global terrestrial surface area (Dregne, 1991; Scanlon et al., 2006), and dryland expansion occurs under climate change, especially in developing countries (Huang et al., 2016). An oasis is a unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid areas that is not only the core of regions’ ecological environment but also the foundation of their economic development, especially in western China, which has been an important part of the “Silk Road” since ancient times. Oases comprising less than 10 % of the total area of arid regions support more than 90 % of the population in these regions of China (Chu et al., 2005; Li et al., 2016; Zhou et al., 2022). The oasis–desert system plays a crucial role in maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity (Zhang and Zhao, 2015). Extensive studies have investigated energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas based on field and remote-sensing observations (Taha et al., 1991; Potchter et al., 2008; Xue et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2019; Zhou et al., 2022) and numerical simulations (Chu et al., 2005; Meng et al., 2009; Georgescu et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2020). In addition, oasis–desert areas located in semiarid regions have been found to be carbon sinks by previous researchers (Tagesson et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2019); thus, they can significantly affect the carbon balance of arid regions and play an increasingly important role within the global carbon cycle.
research objective: Therefore, it is critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in order to achieve the goal of sustainable oasis development. Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis. A quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases; moreover, long-term observations are indispensable.
challenges: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, especially in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin (Zhao et al., 2013), the Aral Sea basin (Stanev et al., 2004; Crétaux et al., 2009), and the Lake Urmia basin (Stone, 2015).
methods: In this study, we present a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems that consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters from 2012 to 2021. Half-hourly turbulent flux data were acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. The hydrometeorological data (including radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles; gradients of air temperature and humidity and of wind speed and direction; and air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles) were observed from automatic weather stations with a 10 min average period as well as the groundwater table data. Moreover, vegetation and soil parameters were also supplemented in the datasets. The data processing and quality control procedure can be divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing.
dataset: The study area comprises the middle and lower reaches of the HRB, located in the arid regions of western China, that receive water from the typical cryosphere of the upper reaches. A total of 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations have been established in these regions since 2012 – 2 superstations and 9 ordinary stations. The dataset of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas reported in this study (including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes; hydrometeorological data; and vegetation and soil parameters) is freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Definition.Question: What is the concept of a phenology camera in the context of data collection for ecological observations?
Definition.Answer: A phenology camera is an instrument used for ecological observations that captures images in a downward-facing orientation to collect data on vegetation. It integrates data acquisition and transmission functions, and the images are processed to calculate indices such as the relative greenness index (GCC). This involves analyzing the red, green, and blue pixel values of the images to determine key phenological parameters such as the start and end of the growing season.

Definition.Question: How is the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange data typically collected in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Definition.Answer: Energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange data in oasis–desert ecosystems are collected using observational datasets that include long-term measurements of these fluxes. The data is acquired through systems like the eddy covariance system and scintillometer, supplemented by auxiliary data on hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters. Automatic weather stations record various environmental metrics with a 10-minute average, contributing to a comprehensive dataset from multiple stations in these regions.

Definition.Question: What is the meaning and significance of 'oasis–desert system' in ecological studies?
Definition.Answer: The 'oasis–desert system' refers to the unique ecological interplay between oases and surrounding desert regions, particularly in arid and semiarid areas. Oases, though covering less than 10% of these areas, support over 90% of the population and are crucial for maintaining ecological stability and agricultural productivity. Understanding the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges in these systems is essential for sustainable development and achieving ecological security, as they play a significant role in the global carbon cycle.

Interpretation.Question: What do the long-term energy, water vapor, and carbon flux observations reveal about the interactions and balance between oasis and desert systems?
Interpretation.Answer: Long-term observations of energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes provide insights into the interactions between oasis and desert systems. They help in understanding the critical balance needed for sustainable development and ecological stability. Such data can indicate how oasis systems can act as carbon sinks, affecting the overall carbon balance in arid regions.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the purpose of integrating phenological camera observations in monitoring vegetation processes within arid and semi-arid regions?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal is to understand and quantify the vegetation processes by calculating indices like the relative greenness index (GCC) and coverage degree, which are crucial for analyzing key phenological parameters such as the start and end of the growing season, especially in oasis-desert ecosystems.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to collect long-term energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange data in oasis-desert ecosystems?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The objective is to gain quantitative insights into the interactions between oasis and desert systems, which are vital for maintaining ecological stability, achieving carbon neutrality, and supporting sustainable development in these regions.

Goal Orientation.Question: What motivates the collection of hydrometeorological and auxiliary data in the middle and lower reaches of arid inland river basins?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The aim is to address the ecological challenges like river drying and land degradation in arid inland river basins, thereby supporting both ecological security and socioeconomic development through informed management and policy-making.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are utilized to compute key phenological parameters such as the start and end of the growing season using data from phenology cameras in the Heihe River Basin?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To compute key phenological parameters like the start and end of the growing season, data from phenology cameras is used to calculate the relative greenness index (GCC) by using the formula GCC=G/(R+G+B), where R, G, B are the pixel values of the image's red, green, and blue channels. This involves invalid value filling and smoothing using filtering techniques to fit the growth curve and determine the parameters.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How are images processed to calculate vegetation cover ratios in the Heihe River Basin's mixed forest station?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Images are processed by first selecting those with moderate lighting. They are then segmented into vegetation and soil areas, calculating the proportion of vegetation pixels within the specified area. The resulting time series data is then smoothed using a filtering process, based on the user's specified time window, to generate the final cover ratio.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What steps are implemented to ensure quality control in data collection for the oasis-desert systems in the Heihe River Basin?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Quality control in data collection involves a comprehensive process that includes the acquisition of half-hourly turbulent flux data using eddy covariance systems and scintillometers. Automatic weather stations capture hydrometeorological data with a 10-minute average period. The data undergoes a three-step process of collection, processing, and archiving/sharing to ensure its quality and reliability.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of using phenology cameras for monitoring vegetation dynamics in arid regions like the Heihe River Basin?
Judgmental.Answer: Phenology cameras can be highly effective for monitoring vegetation dynamics as they provide high-resolution temporal data that can be used to calculate relative greenness indices like the Green Chromatic Coordinate (GCC). These cameras facilitate continuous data collection, which is essential for capturing critical phenological phases such as the start and end of the growing season. However, the effectiveness can be influenced by factors such as camera placement, image resolution, and environmental conditions.

Judgmental.Question: What challenges might arise in maintaining the balance between oasis and desert systems for sustainable development, and how can long-term observational datasets help address these challenges?
Judgmental.Answer: Challenges in maintaining the balance between oasis and desert systems include ecological degradation like river drying, vegetation loss, and land desertification. Long-term observational datasets provide crucial insights into energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange dynamics, helping to understand oasis-desert interactions. This understanding is vital for developing strategies to protect ecological stability and support socioeconomic development, making these datasets instrumental for sustainable oasis management.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, what are the potential advantages of integrating multiple data collection methods, such as eddy covariance systems and automatic weather stations, for studying oasis-desert interactions?
Judgmental.Answer: Integrating multiple data collection methods, such as eddy covariance systems and automatic weather stations, offers a comprehensive view of oasis-desert interactions. Eddy covariance systems provide high-resolution data on turbulent fluxes, while automatic weather stations contribute extensive meteorological data. This integration allows for a robust analysis of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges, enhancing our understanding of ecosystem dynamics and enabling more accurate modeling and predictions.

Request/Directive.Question: Please describe the data collection methods used for obtaining energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert ecosystems, focusing on the instrumentation and techniques involved.
Request/Directive.Answer: The data collection methods for energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert ecosystems involve a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural systems. Half-hourly turbulent flux data are acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. Hydrometeorological data are collected from automatic weather stations with a 10-minute average period, which includes radiation, soil heat flux, soil temperature profiles, gradients of air temperature and humidity, wind speed and direction, air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles. Groundwater table data and supplementary vegetation and soil parameters are also included.

Request/Directive.Answer: Challenges in maintaining long-term observations of ecological interactions in oasis–desert areas include the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, degradation of natural vegetation, intensification of land desertification, and frequent dust storms. These challenges are especially prevalent in inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin, the Aral Sea basin, and the Lake Urmia basin. Ensuring data quality amidst these environmental factors is crucial for accurate long-term monitoring.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify potential datasets available for studying the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in arid regions, and specify their sources and coverage.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential datasets for studying energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in arid regions include observational datasets from the middle and lower reaches of the Heihe River Basin (HRB) in western China, spanning from 2012 to 2021. A total of 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations have been established in these regions, with data freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.
